strapiArticle.title: Champorado
strapiArticle.description: Champorado or tsampurado is a sweet chocolate rice porridge.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Ingredients:

  • 1 cup glutinous rice
  • 4 cups water
  • 3/4 cup cocoa powder
  • 1 cup sugar (adjust to taste)
  • 1/2 teaspoon salt
  • Evaporated milk (for serving)
  • Tuyo (dried fish) or fried dilis (anchovies) (optional, for topping)

Instructions:

  1. Rinse the glutinous rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain the rice.

  2. In a large pot, combine the drained glutinous rice and water. Bring it to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.

  3. Once the water is boiling, lower the heat to medium-low and let the rice simmer for about 15 minutes or until the grains are fully cooked and tender. Stir occasionally to ensure even cooking.

  4. In a separate bowl, whisk together the cocoa powder, sugar, and salt with a little water to form a smooth paste.

  5. Add the cocoa mixture to the pot of cooked glutinous rice. Stir well to combine and continue cooking over medium-low heat for an additional 10-15 minutes, or until the champorado thickens to your desired consistency. Keep stirring to prevent the mixture from sticking to the bottom of the pot.

  6. Once the champorado has reached the desired consistency and the flavors have melded together, remove it from the heat.

  7. Serve the champorado in bowls or mugs. Drizzle some evaporated milk on top according to your preference.

  8. For an optional topping, you can serve the champorado with tuyo (dried fish) or fried dilis (anchovies). The salty fish provides a nice contrast to the sweetness of the champorado.

  9. Stir the champorado before eating to mix in the milk and enjoy it while it's warm.

Champorado is often enjoyed as a comforting breakfast or snack, especially on rainy days. The rich chocolate flavor combined with the creamy milk and optional fish topping creates a unique and delicious Filipino treat.
